mn107:0.2: This training outlined here and all throughout the Nikāyas has to be followed in this order specifically in order to yield the intended result, in keeping with the simile of following directions to arrive at Rājagaha given below. This is because the defilements that each subsequent stage is meant to address will not have become apparent unless the previous ones have been consolidated. For instance, the understanding of what the five hindrances even are is necessarily warped in someone who hasn’t fulfilled the previous steps, and this is why the Buddha did not teach meditation to newcomers (not even [new monks](https://suttas.hillsidehermitage.org/?q=an5.114)), but instead virtue, generosity, restraint, renunciation, and Right View, which was often enough to lead them to stream-entry.
mn107:7.2: i.e., with awareness of the defilements that could potentially become the motivators of any action whatsoever, as opposed to awareness of the soles of the feet touching the floor or similar.
mn107:10.2: See [What The Jhānas Actually Are](https://www.hillsidehermitage.org/what-the-jhanas-actually-are/) and [this follow-up post](https://www.reddit.com/r/HillsideHermitage/comments/1e2hztc/on_thinking_about_jh%C4%81na_by_ven_thanissaro/).
mn107:11.2: This points out how an Arahant truly doesn’t *need* to practice or make effort anymore. However, an Arahant is [categorically incapable of certain acts](https://suttas.hillsidehermitage.org/?q=an9.7) no matter how little effort they make.
mn107:15.3: Note how the qualities listed here go from coarser to more refined, also implying a sequential development.
